newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: South Korean bankers questioned over loans scandal.
newsitem.headline: South Korean bankers questioned over loans scandal.

text.p: South Korean state prosecutors on Wednesday questioned two bankers in connection with a loans-for-kickbacks scandal involving failed Hanbo Steel Co KS, a prosecution official said.
The official did not name the bankers, but said one was a branch manager of Korea First Bank, Hanbo's main creditor, and another an executive at the Commercial Bank of Korea.
State prosecutors last week reopened their enquiry into political influence-peddling that allowed Hanbo Steel to borrow $5.8 billion in largely unsecured loans.
The new probe is focusing on rumours that President Kim Young-sam's second son, Hyun-chul, received more than 200 billion won ($225 million) in kickbacks.
Three bankers are now on trial in the bribery scandal. They are Korea First Bank's former presidents Rhee Chul-soo and Sheen Kwang-shik and head of Chohung Bank Woo Chan-mok.
Seven other people including a former cabinet minister, Hanbo founder Chung Tae-soo and his chief accountant, three close aides to President Kim and an opposition lawmaker are also on trial.
President Kim apologised last month for the Hanbo furore and reshuffled his cabinet. Junior Kim issued a statement saying he was ready to receive punishment for any wrongdoings found.
The younger Kim was exonerated by prosecutors last month after being questioned in connection to the scandal.
The opposition has slammed the investigation as a white-wash. The government last week replaced Choi Byung-koog, who had led the Hanbo investigation, with Shim Je-ryoon.
Kim Hyun-chul is also due to testify before a National Assembly hearing on Hanbo in April which will be broadcast live. Parliament launch a 45-day special investigation on Friday.
